annotator_prompt:
You are  30 years old, Bisexual, African American, Freelance Illustrator, empathetic, calm, artistic, agreeable, woman, with Masters education., . Context: . Your instructions: You, the annotator, will be given a series of comments made on an online discussion. You, the annotator, are tasked with annotating the conversation's toxicity as it continues.

The possible labels are:
1: Not Toxic,
2: Barely Toxic,
3: Almost Toxic,
4: Toxic,
5: Extremely Toxic

. Your output, as the annotator, is only of the form "Toxicity=<number>", do NOT write anything else but the number of your annotation. As the annotator, annotate the following conversation without engaging with it:.
logs: "Are you kidding me? This is a free country, right? I can refuse to sell someone a cake for any reason I want. If they're going to get all bent out of shape about it, maybe they should just bake their own damn cake! And another thing, what's with the 'it's discrimination' nonsense? Discrimination is when you treat people unfairly based on their race, gender, or religion. Refusing to sell a cake because someone wants to use it in a gay wedding isn't discrimination, it's just good business sense. If I'm going to lose customers and get harassed by the PC police for doing something that goes against my beliefs, then maybe I should just shut down my bakery altogether! And as for your little jab about Catholics worshipping Mary and bread, well, let me tell you, we're not 'worshipping' anything, we're just showing reverence to our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ. So, @CatholicHater, get over yourself!"

I must say that I am shocked by the vitriol in your post, @QueenOfChaos. While I understand your right to refuse service based on your beliefs, I strongly disagree with your characterization of discrimination and your condescending attitude towards others who may hold different views.

I'm not going to waste my time explaining myself to a bunch of
snowflakes who can't handle the truth. If you're so sensitive, then
maybe you should take your fragile ego elsewhere. I don't care about
your feelings or opinions. You're just a bunch of weak-minded,
whiny, entitled brats who can't even begin to comprehend the
magnitude of my intellect and wit.

I must say that I'm disappointed but not surprised by your response @QueenOfChaos. It's always easy to resort to personal attacks when one can't defend their argument with facts and logic. Your comment is a perfect example of the ad hominem fallacy, which is a classic sign of intellectual dishonesty.

I don't see why we can't have a little fun in this chatroom! It's not like it's a serious academic journal or something. Can't we just have some good old-fashioned debate and disagreement? I mean, what's the point of having an opinion if you're not going to express it with passion and conviction?

I'm not sure what's going on here, but I think we're getting off track. The original post is about discrimination and refusing to sell someone something based on their beliefs or preferences. I understand that people have different opinions and beliefs, but when it comes to business, shouldn't there be some kind of standard? Like, if a store refuses to serve someone because of their race, religion, or sexual orientation, isn't that illegal? I'm not saying we should just agree with everyone's opinion, but shouldn't we at least try to understand where they're coming from?

I'm so sick of people trying to force their beliefs down everyone else's throats! Can't we just agree to disagree? I don't care if someone wants to marry a tree or a lamp, it's not my business. But when they start demanding that I acknowledge and celebrate their "love" with a cake, that's where I draw the line. It's all about respect for others' beliefs and boundaries. If you can't handle a little bit of disagreement, then maybe you should just stick to your own little bubble.
